cards.title: When the leotards come off / At home with Mexican wrestlers

item.title: When the leotards come off: at home with Mexican wrestlers
item.trailText: They may not reveal their real names, but these legendary luchadores let photographer Katinka Herbert into their homes to meet their pitbulls, check out their trophy rooms – and watch them weightlift with concrete blocks
item.standFirst:
They may not reveal their real names, but these legendary luchadores let photographer Katinka Herbert into their homes to meet their pitbulls, check out their trophy rooms – and watch them weightlift with concrete blocks

  • SLAM! Lucha Libre’s Superheroes of the Ring is at Studio 2, London, from 9-12 July

cards.title: Women's World Cup / Japan beat England

item.title: Women's World Cup: Japan beat England
item.trailText: The first senior England team to reach a international semi-final since 1990 takes on the defending champions. Here are the best photos of the match
item.standFirst:
They were the first senior England team to reach an international semi-final since Lineker and co at the 1990 World Cup. But, like their predecessors, they fell agonisingly short as an injury-time goal from Japan knocked them out of the tournament. Here are the best photos of the match
• Read the match report
• Japan beat England 1-0 – as it happened

displayImages.caption: The players emerge before the match, with England’s Laura Bassett and Fara Williams in white. Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The players emerge before the match, with England’s Laura Bassett and Fara Williams in white.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The players emerge before the match, with England’s Laura Bassett and Fara Williams in white.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: The sun’s beating down while the players and the crowd, which is the second highest in the competition thus far, sing the national anthems. Photograph: Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The sun’s beating down while the players and the crowd, which is the second highest in the competition thus far, sing the national anthems.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The sun’s beating down while the players and the crowd, which is the second highest in the competition thus far, sing the national anthems.

displayImages.caption: England defender Laura Bassett gets stuck in as Japan forward Mana Iwabuchi tries to evade her. Photograph: Erich Schlegel/USA Today Sports
displayImages.altText: England defender Laura Bassett gets stuck in as Japan forward Mana Iwabuchi tries to evade her.
displayImages.cleanCaption: England defender Laura Bassett gets stuck in as Japan forward Mana Iwabuchi tries to evade her.

displayImages.caption: Japan’s Rumi Utsugi (wearing 13) is a menace. She’s pictured shielding the ball from Katie Chapman. Photograph: Jeff McIntosh/AP
displayImages.altText: Japan’s Rumi Utsugi (wearing 13) is a menace. She’s pictured shielding the ball from Katie Chapman.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Japan’s Rumi Utsugi (wearing 13) is a menace. She’s pictured shielding the ball from Katie Chapman.

displayImages.caption: In the 32nd minute, Claire Rafferty gets the wrong side of Saori Ariyoshi of Japan and, in her desperation, shoves the Japanese player in the back ... Photograph: Matthew Lewis/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: In the 32nd minute, Claire Rafferty gets the wrong side of Saori Ariyoshi of Japan and, in her desperation, shoves the Japanese player in the back ...
displayImages.cleanCaption: In the 32nd minute, Claire Rafferty gets the wrong side of Saori Ariyoshi of Japan and, in her desperation, shoves the Japanese player in the back ...
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Matthew Lewis/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Ariyoshi goes down, but was the contact inside the box or out? The referee says inside, so Japan have a penalty. Photograph: Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Ariyoshi goes down to win a penalty
displayImages.cleanCaption: Ariyoshi goes down, but was the contact inside the box or out? The referee says inside, so Japan have a penalty.

displayImages.caption: England’s goalkeeper Karen Bardsley is sent the wrong way by Aya Miyama, who took an eternity to strike her shot. Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: England’s goalkeeper Karen Bardsley is sent the wrong way by Aya Miyama, who took an eternity to strike her shot.
displayImages.cleanCaption: England’s goalkeeper Karen Bardsley is sent the wrong way by Aya Miyama, who took an eternity to strike her shot.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Japan players celebrate. They’ve hardly been the dominant team thus far, but they’ve got the first goal at least. Photograph: Geoff Robins/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Japan players celebrate.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Japan players celebrate. They’ve hardly been the dominant team thus far, but they’ve got the first goal at least.

displayImages.caption: Soon there’s more controversy at the other end of the pitch as Steph Houghton goes down under a challenge from Saori Ariyoshi. Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Controversy as Steph Houghton goes down under a challenge from Saori Ariyoshi.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Soon there’s more controversy at the other end of the pitch as Steph Houghton goes down under a challenge from Saori Ariyoshi.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: To be fair, it hardly qualified as a ‘challenge’. Houghton went down under minimal contact and quite how or why the referee has called that a penalty is mystery. At worst there was a minor collision of the two players’ feet as Houghton looked to turn. Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Controversy as Steph Houghton goes down under a challenge from Saori Ariyoshi.
displayImages.cleanCaption: To be fair, it hardly qualified as a ‘challenge’. Houghton went down under minimal contact and quite how or why the referee has called that a penalty is mystery. At worst there was a minor collision of the two players’ feet as Houghton looked to turn.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Fara Williams steps up and slams the resulting spot-kick home. 1-1! Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Fara Williams steps up and slams a spot-kick home to make it 1-1
displayImages.cleanCaption: Fara Williams steps up and slams the resulting spot-kick home. 1-1!
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Well, that’s evened things up. Some will say neither penalty was deserved. England aren’t complaining now.  Photograph: Todd Korol/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: England celebrate
displayImages.cleanCaption: Well, that’s evened things up. Some will say neither penalty was deserved. England aren’t complaining now.

displayImages.caption: In fact, they’re positively delirious. Photograph: Dan Riedlhuber/EPA
displayImages.altText: England celebrate
displayImages.cleanCaption: In fact, they’re positively delirious.

displayImages.caption: Katie Chapman gives Williams a hug. So, it’s all square at half-time. Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Katie Chapman gives Williams a hug.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Katie Chapman gives Williams a hug. So, it’s all square at half-time.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: The second half is a cagey affair. Here, Jill Scott makes ground down the left flank. Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The second half is a cagey affair, albeit with England twice hitting the crossbar. Here, Jill Scott makes ground down the left flank.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The second half is a cagey affair. Here, Jill Scott makes ground down the left flank.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Toni Duggan rattles the bar with an ambitious strike. That was mighty close. Photograph: Geoff Robins/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Toni Duggan rattles the bar with an ambitious strike. That was mighty close.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Toni Duggan rattles the bar with an ambitious strike. That was mighty close.

displayImages.caption: England’s coach Mark Sampson gives out instructions. They’re in the ascendancy as the half wears on. But normal time is fast running out. Photograph: Matthew Lewis/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: England’s coach Mark Sampson gives out instructions. They’re in the ascendancy as the half wears on. But normal time is fast running out.
displayImages.cleanCaption: England’s coach Mark Sampson gives out instructions. They’re in the ascendancy as the half wears on. But normal time is fast running out.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Matthew Lewis/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: Then, two minutes into injury time, England do the unthinkable – they score an own goal. Lauru Bassett, looking to turn away a dangerous cross, toe-pokes the ball up and over her keeper, sending it in off the underside of the crossbar.  Photograph: Todd Korol/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Then, two minutes into injury time, England do the unthinkable – they score an own goal. Lauru Bassett, looking to turn away a dangerous cross, toe-poked the ball up and over her keeper, sending it in off the underside of the crossbar.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Then, two minutes into injury time, England do the unthinkable – they score an own goal. Lauru Bassett, looking to turn away a dangerous cross, toe-pokes the ball up and over her keeper, sending it in off the underside of the crossbar.

displayImages.caption: A stunning and galling conclusion for England.  Photograph: Ronald Martinez/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: A stunning and galling conclusion.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A stunning and galling conclusion for England.

displayImages.caption: England’s players are distraught. The final whistle has gone and they’re out of the World Cup. Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images
displayImages.altText: England’s players are distraught. The final whistle has gone and they’re out of the World Cup.
displayImages.cleanCaption: England’s players are distraught. The final whistle has gone and they’re out of the World Cup.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Mike Hewitt/Fifa via Getty Images

displayImages.caption: No one is more choked up than Laura Bassett. Photograph: Ronald Martinez/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Laura Bassett cries.
displayImages.cleanCaption: No one is more choked up than Laura Bassett.

displayImages.caption: Shades of Paul Gascoigne all over again. Photograph: Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Shades of Paul Gascoigne all over again.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Shades of Paul Gascoigne all over again.

image.caption: The players emerge before the match, with England’s Laura Bassett and Fara Williams in white. Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images
image.altText: The players emerge before the match, with England’s Laura Bassett and Fara Williams in white.
image.cleanCaption: The players emerge before the match, with England’s Laura Bassett and Fara Williams in white.
image.cleanCredit: Photograph: Maddie Meyer/Fifa via Getty Images

image.caption: The sun’s beating down while the players and the crowd, which is the second highest in the competition thus far, sing the national anthems. Photograph: Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images

image.cleanCaption: The sun’s beating down while the players and the crowd, which is the second highest in the competition thus far, sing the national anthems.

image.caption: In the 32nd minute, Claire Rafferty gets the wrong side of Saori Ariyoshi of Japan and, in her desperation, shoves the Japanese player in the back ... Photograph: Matthew Lewis/Fifa via Getty Images
image.altText: In the 32nd minute, Claire Rafferty gets the wrong side of Saori Ariyoshi of Japan and, in her desperation, shoves the Japanese player in the back ...

cards.title: Athena's best posters / Not just Tennis Girl and Muscle Man Cradling Baby
cards.rawTitle: Not just Tennis Girl and Muscle Man Cradling Baby

item.title: Athena's best posters: not just Tennis Girl and Muscle Man Cradling Baby
item.trailText: Leaping dolphins, topless men posing with tyres ... in the 80s and 90s, Athena was the go-to place for all your soft-focus fantasies. As it relaunches, we celebrate the pick of the high-shine posters once pinned to every bedroom wall
item.standFirst:
Leaping dolphins, topless men posing with tyres ... in the 80s and 90s, Athena was the go-to place for all your soft-focus fantasies. As it relaunches online, we celebrate the pick of the high-shine posters once pinned to every bedroom wall

  • Why Athena was more than just a naff purveyor of mild erotica

cards.title: For sale / Blur's very big house in the country
cards.rawTitle: Blur's very big house in the country

item.title: For sale: Blur's very big house in the country
item.trailText: The six-bedroom country house in Bedfordshire that inspired Blur’s song Country House is on the market and would make a great escape
item.standFirst: The six-bedroom country house in Bedfordshire that inspired Blur’s song Country House is on the market and would make a great escape
item.body:
So you think Modern Life is Rubbish? Surely There’s No Other Way but to pack up and move to a house, a very big house in the country: 20 years after Blur’s Britpop battle with Oasis made headlines, the property that inspired their No 1 single Country House is on the market.

This Grade II-listed home was bought by David Balfe, who founded record label Food in 1984. He signed Blur – called Seymour at the time before he and his label partner convinced them to change their name – and directed the band’s first two music videos, She’s So High and There’s No Other Way. An integral part of the Popscene, you might say.

But by 1994, disenchanted with the alternative scene in the years of grunge, Balfe decided to sell the label to EMI and semi-retire with his young family to the country. This inspired lead singer Damon Albarn to pen Blur’s first No 1 hit about a “professional cynic, but my heart’s not in it” who is tired of living life to the limit and escapes to the “rural charm” of the country.

Now the large, traditional-styled family home, which has a separate (Al)barn annexe and, for those who have had enough of city parklife, is set in a conservation area with elements dating back to the 17th century, is on the market for a guide price of £2m through agent Savills.

The Grade II-listed, six-bedroom home is set in four acres of grounds backing on to the Barton Hills area of outstanding natural beauty in the village of Barton-le-Clay, Bedfordshire. So crack The Magic Whip and get saving!

displayImages.altText: Surreal estate: The Bury

cards.title: The Undercurrent / Forget the TPP, does a secret global court spell the end of democracy?
cards.rawTitle: Forget the TPP, does a secret global court spell the end of democracy?

item.title: The Undercurrent: Forget the TPP, does a secret global court spell the end of democracy?
item.trailText: With a series of murky international trade agreements like the TPP being negotiated, will a secret court give corporations the power to erode the rights of nation states?
item.standFirst: With a series of murky international trade agreements like the TPP being negotiated, will a secret court give corporations the power to erode the rights of nation states? The TPP includes an Investor State Dispute Settlement clause that allows a secret court (ICSID; International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes) with global reach to arbitrate disputes between multinationals and the countries they operate in, potentially forcing governments to change sovereign laws or pay compensation to companies if they lose a case. The Undercurrent shines a light on the issue and asks – is the TPP the end of democracy? The Undercurrent is an online news show billing itself as an antidote to the five-second soundbite. Creators Jen Dainer and Dan Graetz say it is the show they wish existed – so they created it themselves

cards.title: Your June wildlife photos / Badgers, bullfrogs and birdsong

item.title: Badgers, bullfrogs and birdsong: your June wildlife photos
item.trailText: We asked you to share your May pictures of the wildlife around the world with which we share our outdoor spaces. Here’s our pick of the best
item.standFirst:
We asked you to share your June pictures of the wildlife around the world with which we share our outdoor spaces. Here’s our pick of the best

  • Join in July’s Wildlife on your doorstep via GuardianWitness

displayImages.caption:
Lost his way
This badger seemed to have lost his way and was searching in the village for a way back to his burrow
Photograph: Ann Mulelly/GuardianWitness
displayImages.altText: Lost his way
displayImages.cleanCaption:

cards.title: Chocolate fondue and duty-free / Inside North Korea's new airport

item.title: Inside North Korea's new airport
item.trailText: Chocolate fondue fountains, shiny duty-free shops and purged architects: to the delight of supreme leader Kim Jong-un, Pyongyang International is ready for takeoff
item.standFirst: Chocolate fondue fountains, shiny duty-free shops and purged architects: to the delight of supreme leader Kim Jong-un, Pyongyang International is ready for takeoff

displayImages.caption: A view from the runway of the new Pyongyang International Airport terminal, which opens on 1 July.  Photograph: KCNA/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A view from the runway of the new Pyongyang International Airport, which opens on 1 July.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A view from the runway of the new Pyongyang International Airport terminal, which opens on 1 July.

displayImages.caption: The airport was inspected by supreme leader Kim Jong-un in a visit publicised on state media last week. State news service KCNA reported that Kim Jong-un was ‘very satisfied to see the terminal well built in harmony with modern aesthetic taste and national character’, and praised the soldier-builders for their efforts Photograph: KNS/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The airport was inspected by supreme leader Kim Jong-un in a visit publicised on state media last week. State news service KCNA reported that Kim Jong-un was ‘very satisfied to see the terminal well built in harmony with modern aesthetic taste and national character’, and praised the soldier-builders for their efforts
displayImages.cleanCaption: The airport was inspected by supreme leader Kim Jong-un in a visit publicised on state media last week. State news service KCNA reported that Kim Jong-un was ‘very satisfied to see the terminal well built in harmony with modern aesthetic taste and national character’, and praised the soldier-builders for their efforts

displayImages.caption: Visitors to the new terminal will be greeted by a range of food and drink options, including an espresso bar and a chocolate fondue fountain Photograph: KCNA/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Visitors to the new terminal will be greeted by a range of food and drink options, including an espresso bar and a chocolate fondue fountain
displayImages.cleanCaption: Visitors to the new terminal will be greeted by a range of food and drink options, including an espresso bar and a chocolate fondue fountain

displayImages.caption: Conspicuous by his absence from the delegation was the design director of the country’s recent infrastructure drive: Ma Won-chun. The architect was among those those reportedly purged in May 2015 Photograph: KNS/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Conspicuous by his absence from the delegation was the design director of the country’s recent infrastructure drive: Ma Won-chun. The architect was among those those reportedly purged in May 2015
displayImages.cleanCaption: Conspicuous by his absence from the delegation was the design director of the country’s recent infrastructure drive: Ma Won-chun. The architect was among those those reportedly purged in May 2015

displayImages.caption: Kim Jong-un was photographed inspecting the duty-free shops of the new terminal with his wife, former singer Ri Sol-ju Photograph: KNS/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Kim Jong-un was photographed inspecting the duty free shops of the new terminal with his wife, former singer Ri Sol-ju
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kim Jong-un was photographed inspecting the duty-free shops of the new terminal with his wife, former singer Ri Sol-ju

displayImages.caption: Carriers using the new terminal are expected to mostly be from North Korea’s strongest allies, Russia and China. Though western tourist trips dropped by 40% last year, 100,000 Chinese visited the country, NK News reports Photograph: KCNA/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Carriers using the new terminal are expected to mostly be from North Korea’s strongest allies, Russia and China. Though western tourist trips dropped by 40% last year, 100,000 Chinese visited the country, NK News reports
displayImages.cleanCaption: Carriers using the new terminal are expected to mostly be from North Korea’s strongest allies, Russia and China. Though western tourist trips dropped by 40% last year, 100,000 Chinese visited the country, NK News reports

displayImages.caption: In April 2015, Kim Jong-un called for ‘artistry, visual quality and cultural level in designing the logo of the airport, signboards of service networks and posters’ ahead of Pyongyang International’s opening Photograph: KCNA/Reuters
displayImages.altText: In April 2015, Kim Jong-un called for ‘artistry, visual quality and cultural level in designing the logo of the airport, signboards of service networks and posters’ ahead of Pyongyang International’s opening
displayImages.cleanCaption: In April 2015, Kim Jong-un called for ‘artistry, visual quality and cultural level in designing the logo of the airport, signboards of service networks and posters’ ahead of Pyongyang International’s opening

displayImages.caption: Kim Jong-un is far more focussed on air travel than his father, who hardly ever flew. He has been photographed in state media alongside light aircraft, reportedly produced in North Korea, and in 2014, lifted the ban on domestic air travel, according to sources quoted in Daily NK Photograph: KCNA/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Kim Jong-un is far more focussed on air travel than his father, who hardly ever flew. He has been photographed in state media alongside light aircraft, reportedly produced in North Korea, and in 2014, lifted the ban on domestic air travel, according to sources quoted in Daily NK
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kim Jong-un is far more focussed on air travel than his father, who hardly ever flew. He has been photographed in state media alongside light aircraft, reportedly produced in North Korea, and in 2014, lifted the ban on domestic air travel, according to sources quoted in Daily NK

displayImages.caption: The new terminal is not the only airport planned. Wonsan, on the east coast, is converting its military airport for civilian use, alongside an underwater hotel, flower park and exposition centre. This, combined with the outward-facing design of Pyongyang’s new terminal, is the most overt sign yet of the regime’s increasing desire to attract foreign visitors – and foreign money Photograph: Rodong Sinmun/EPA
displayImages.altText: The new terminal is not the only airport planned. Wonsan, on the east coast, is converting its military airport for civilian use, alongside an underwater hotel, flower park and exposition centre. This, combined with the outward-facing design of Pyongyang’s new terminal, is the most overt sign yet of the regime’s increasing desire to attract foreign visitors – and foreign money
displayImages.cleanCaption: The new terminal is not the only airport planned. Wonsan, on the east coast, is converting its military airport for civilian use, alongside an underwater hotel, flower park and exposition centre. This, combined with the outward-facing design of Pyongyang’s new terminal, is the most overt sign yet of the regime’s increasing desire to attract foreign visitors – and foreign money
